sn43.15:1.1: Nibbāna is the truth since delusion has ceased (MN 140:26.2).
sn43.16:1.1: This is a common metaphor, eg. Snp 5.18:1.3.
sn43.17:1.1: For this term and the next, see Dhp 36:1, Thag 2.46:2.3.
sn43.19:1.1: “Undecrepit” (ajajjara) doesn’t appear elsewhere in Pali. However, Buddhist Sanskrit texts sometimes use jarjara (“decrepitude”) in definitions of old age in dependent origination (Nidānasaṁyukta 16.15, Pratītyasamutpādavibhaṅgasūtra 15b, Pratītyasamutpādādivibhaṅganirdeśasūtra 118, Dharmaskandha 16v2).
sn43.20:1.1: “Everlasting” (dhuva) is normally a synonym of “permanent” (nicca). It is used of Brahmā (SN 6.4:1.4), and of Nibbāna at Iti 43:4.4.
sn43.21:1.1: “Not worn out” (apalokita) is apparently unique in this sense. “Wearing out” (paloka) is a characteristic of conditioned things (SN 35.84:2.3).
sn43.22:1.1: Normally anidassana means “invisible” (DN 33:1.10.76) or “formless” (MN 21:14.8), although it is sometimes interpreted to mean Nibbāna (DN 11:85.18). While Nibbāna is, of course, formless and invisible, I believe this is the only place anidassana unambiguously refers to Nibbāna.
sn43.30:1.1: This term and the next are commonly used of individuals who have realized Nibbāna (AN 6.46:6.5, SN 51.22:2.2).
sn43.35:1.1: Normally a term for the mind developed through love, etc. (MN 21:11.14), or for good acts with pleasant outcomes (AN 3.23:2.1, MN 57:9.2).
sn43.39:1.1: “Not clinging” (anālaya) is part of the standard definition of the third noble truth (SN 56.11:4.7).
sn43.40:1.1: Snp 5.11:3.2. | This series of terms is used of the Buddha (SN 42.7) or one’s own good deeds (AN 3.51:2.4).
